SpoutLibrary

https://​spout​.zeal​.co​/

Spout SDK dll compatible with any C++ compiler

Based on the CodeProject :

"HowTo: Export C++ classes from a DLL" by Alex Blekhman.

http://​www​.codeproject​.com​/Articles​/28969​/HowTo-Export-C-classes-from-a-DLL

Building the library

The "VS2017" folder contains Visual Studio projects to build the dll.

The Spout SDK source files should be located in a folder "SpoutGL" two levels above the project folder.

Open the SpoutLibrary solution, change to "Release" and build the project.  SpoutLibrary.dll and SpoutLibrary.lib will be in the Win32\Release or x64\Release folder.

Also refer to "Building the libraries.pdf" for details on building the libraries using CMake.

Building applications with the library

  • Include SpoutLibrary.h in your application header file.

  • Include SpoutLibrary.lib in your project for the linker.

  • Include SpoutLibrary.dll in the application executable folder.

All functions are the same as described for in the Spout SDK documentation.

Using the library

Refer to the source code of the SpoutLibrary example.

1) Include SpoutLibrary.h in your application header file

#include "SpoutLibrary.h"

2) create a spout sender object pointer

SPOUTLIBRARY * sender;

3) Create an instance of the library

sender = GetSpout();

4) Use the object as usual :

sender->SendTexture(...) etc.

Compare with the graphics sender example using the Spout SDK source files.

Sender

SendFbo, SendTexture and SendImage create or update a sender as required.

  • If a sender has not been created yet :

    • Make sure Spout has been initialized and OpenGL context is available

    • Perform a compatibility check for GL/DX interop

    • If compatible, create interop for GL/DX transfer

    • If not compatible, create a shared texture for the sender

    • Create a sender using the DX11 shared texture handle

  • If the sender exists, test for size change :

    • If compatible, update the shared textures and GL/DX interop

    • If not compatible, re-create the class shared texture to the new size

    • Update the sender and class variables

SetSenderName
void SetSenderName(
const char* sendername = nullptr
)

Set name for sender creation

If no name is specified, the executable name is used.

SetSenderFormat
void SetSenderFormat(
DWORD dwFormat
)

Set the sender DX11 shared texture format

ReleaseSender
void ReleaseSender(
DWORD dwMsec = 0
)

Close receiver and release resources.

A new sender is created or updated by all sending functions

SendFbo
bool SendFbo(
GLuint FboID,
unsigned int width,
unsigned int height,
bool bInvert = true
)

Send texture attached to fbo.

The fbo must be currently bound.  The sending texture can be larger than the size that the sender is set up for.  For example, if the application is using only a portion of the allocated texture space, such as for Freeframe plugins. (The 2.006 equivalent is DrawToSharedTexture).

SendTexture
bool SendTexture(
GLuint TextureID,
GLuint TextureTarget,
unsigned int width,
unsigned int height,
bool bInvert = true,
GLuint HostFBO = 0
)

Send OpenGL texture.

SendImage
bool SendImage(
const unsigned char* pixels,
unsigned int width,
unsigned int height,
GLenum glFormat = GL_RGBA,
bool bInvert = false
)

Send pixel image

Sender name

double GetFps()

Sender frame rate

GetFrame
long GetFrame()

Sender frame number

GetHandle

Sender share handle

Receiver

ReceiveTexture and ReceiveImage

  • Connect to a sender

  • Set class variables for sender name, width and height

  • If the sender has changed size, set a flag for the application to update receiving texture or image which is re-allocated if IsUpdated() returns true.

  • Copy the sender shared texture to the user texture or image.

SetReceiverName
void SetReceiverName(
const char * SenderName
)

Specify sender for connection

The application will not connect to any other  unless the user selects one If that sender closes, the application will wait for the nominated sender to open If no name is specified, the receiver will connect to the active sender

ReleaseReceiver
void ReleaseReceiver()

Close receiver and release resources ready to connect to another sender

ReceiveTexture
bool ReceiveTexture(
GLuint TextureID = 0,
GLuint TextureTarget = 0,
bool bInvert = false,
GLuint HostFbo = 0
)

If no arguments are passed : Connect to a sender and retrieve shared texture details

The texture can then be accessed using :

  • BindSharedTexture();

  • UnBindSharedTexture();

  • GetSharedTextureID();

For a valid OpenGL texture passed :

Copy the sender shared texture

The receiving texture can only be RGBA of dimension (width * height) and must be re-allocated if IsUpdated() returns true

ReceiveImage
bool ReceiveImage(
unsigned char *pixels,
GLenum glFormat = GL_RGBA,
bool bInvert = false,
GLuint HostFbo = 0
)

Copy the sender texture to image pixels.

The receiving image can be RGBA, RGB or BGR of dimension (width * height) and must be re-allocated if IsUpdated() returns true

IsUpdated
bool IsUpdated()

Query whether the sender has changed.

Must be checked at every cycle before receiving data.

If this is not done, the receiving functions fail.

IsConnected
bool IsConnected()

Query sender connection.

If the sender closes, receiving functions return false, but connection can be tested at any time.

IsFrameNew
bool IsFrameNew()

Query received frame status

The receiving texture or pixel buffer is refreshed if the sender has produced a new frame This can be queried to process texture data only for new frames

Log utilities
OpenSpoutConsole
void OpenSpoutConsole()

Open console window.

A console window opens without logs.  Useful for debugging with console output.

CloseSpoutConsole
void CloseSpoutConsole(
bool bWarning = false
)

Close console window.

The optional warning displays a MessageBox if user notification is required.

EnableSpoutLog
void EnableSpoutLog()

Enable logging to the console.

Logs are displayed in a console window.  Useful for program development.

EnableSpoutLogFile
void EnableSpoutLogFile(
const char *filename,
bool append = false
)

Enable logging to a file with optional append.

You can instead, or additionally to a console window, specify output to a text file with the extension of your choice Example : EnableSpoutLogFile("Sender.log"); The log file is re-created every time the application starts unless you specify to append to the existing one : Example : EnableSpoutLogFile("Sender.log", true); The file is saved in the %AppData% folder unless you specify the full path : C:>Users>username>AppData>Roaming>Spout You can find and examine the log file after the application has run.

GetSpoutLog
std::string GetSpoutLog()

Return the log file as a string

ShowSpoutLogs
void ShowSpoutLogs()

Show the log file folder in Windows Explorer

DisableSpoutLog
void DisableSpoutLog()

Disable logging to console and file

void SetSpoutLogLevel(
LogLevel level
)

Set the current log level

SpoutMessageBox
int SpoutMessageBox(
const char * message,
DWORD dwMilliseconds = 0
)

MessageBox dialog with optional timeout.

Used where a Windows MessageBox would interfere with the application GUI.  The dialog closes itself if a timeout is specified.

SpoutMessageBox
int SpoutMessageBox(
HWND hwnd,
LPCSTR message,
LPCSTR caption,
UINT uType,
DWORD dwMilliseconds = 0
)

MessageBox dialog with standard arguments.  Replaces an existing MessageBox call.

2.006 compatibility

These functions are not necessary for Version 2.007.  But are retained for compatibility with existing 2.006 code.

OpenGL utilities
CreateOpenGL
bool CreateOpenGL()

Create an OpenGL window and context for situations where there is none.  Not used if applications already have an OpenGL context.  Always call CloseOpenGL afterwards.
